rdf:Description.dc:title: Fired clay study (painted plaster) of 4 running buffalo
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Petersen, Christian, 1885-1961.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Iowa State University--Engineering; Artists--Iowa; Sculptors--Iowa; Sculpture; Sculpture techniques
rdf:Description.dc:description: Top view. This painted plaster study of 4 buffalo running was created by Christian Petersen during his employment by the Public Works of Art Project (PWAP) in Iowa City, Iowa. The study was a preliminary model for a proposed bridgehead sculpture in Des Moines that was never authorized. This was the only small sculpture Petersen created for the PWAP.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Letter from Charles Scribner's Sons, NY
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Petersen, Christian, 1885-1961.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fox Indians; Indians of North America--Iowa; Indians of North America--Iowa; Artists--Iowa; Letters
rdf:Description.dc:description: February 5, 1936 Hiss Halla Rhode Miss Bessie Coon 1357 East 13th Street Des Moines, Iowa Dear Miss Rhode and Miss Coon: Again I am writing you about the pictures for CHA-KI-SHI. I had a talk with our printer yesterday and he said that the pictures presented great difficulties, the color ones calling for absolutely the most expensive form of reproduction. We have to make this book to sell for a dollar or less, and as the pictures stand at present we cannot do it. I am going to present to you the blackest side of the picture—all The bookmaking problems that arise with these pictures. 1) The color is so expensive that we probably can use only four (if that many) color pictures in the book. If the artist had known how to prepare pictures for flat color reproduction it would have been possible to have more. If we can only use four in color, he will need to redraw the others in black and white. For this we could probably pay a small sum. What was your arrangement with him? 2) The pictures are not planned with any shape of book in mind--that is, many of them would have to be set in the wrong way so children would have to turn the book around to look at the picture—poor for a primary book. 3) Because of the use of a soft crayon in some of the black-and- whites, the pictures are not sharp and when reduced will be very black and not very clear. Please don't have him do any more drawings until we can work out some solution of this. To be perfectly frank, I don't think the drawings in their present condition will make a very attractive book. I want to do everything I can to help out on this and to make it a nice- looking book. Will you write me about your arrangement with the artist, and what you think might be done? I wish we could have them redrawn here, but this of course we would not do with his work. The text of CHA-KI-SHI is so good that I do want the pictures to be up to the standard it sets. Yours very sincerely
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:format: Letter; 20.3x25.4 cm Typewritten letter

rdf:Description.dc:title: Letter from George Nerney to Christian Petersen
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Petersen, Christian, 1885-1961.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Artists--Iowa; Petersen family; Childrens' stories--Pictorial works; Livres d'artistes
rdf:Description.dc:description: Dec 27 40 Dear Peter.- The portrait etching of Mary arrived as a complete surprise and I have had great joy in having her with me all day. Every line is the line of a sculptor which to me gives it a richness of form that a painter cannot feel. It is so charmingly simple that it seems happily appropriate for a little girl.- "Hello Beautiful" has quite upset me with stirrings that lead to rebellion against all of the confining irritations of the factory, but it has

rdf:Description.dc:description: also taken me far away with memories and still lingering desires. It has somehow pictured to me something of your life that I have been yearning to know about in hoping you have found something that soothes the strange undercurrents which sometimes reach the surface and are transformed as visual art. rdf:Description.dc:description: exacts as you well know. I hope the spoons (?) did not disappoint you. After enjoying Hello Beautiful I feel that Mrs. Petersen will see in them something that will be very satisfying to you. I recall the cutting on the Jackson house of the New Orleans spoon (?) as one of the most masterly pieces of works anyone could do. rdf:Description.dc:title: Anson Marston Medal
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Petersen, Christian, 1885-1961.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Iowa State University--Engineering; Artists--Iowa; Awards--Iowa; Medals; Special Collections Department, Iowa State University Library
rdf:Description.dc:description: Front view. Medal awarded for achievement in engineering by an ISU alumnus, in the fields of technical construction, design, planning, development, and management, as well as teaching and research. The award was established by Iowa State College through the generosity of Anson Marston, Professor of Civil Engineering (1892-1920) and Dean of Engineering (1904-1932). He was named Dean Emeritus in 1938. The medal was originally to be made of gold, and awarded no more than once a year. This medal is one of two, which was sent to Christian Petersen by the Medallic Art Company (New York, NY) for him to use in exhibits as needed. Recto: depicts Iowa State University College of Engineering Dean Anson Marston in profile, wearing a suit and tie. Verso: depicts a scene with bridges, a river, a dam, a tower, and buildings. Recto inscription: THE ANSON MARSTON AWARD-IOWA STATE COLLEGE. Verso inscription: AWARDED FOR ACHIEVEMENT IN ENGINEERING.
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:format: Medal; 4.1 X 0.3 Medal cast in bronze

rdf:Description.dc:title: A Mountain Interlude
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Petersen, Charlotte d.1985.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Artists--Iowa; Kentucky--History; Essays
rdf:Description.dc:description: A MOUNTAIN INTERLUDE The air was thick and heavy with sun-heat. No shadow quivered. The men stood fixed and stared. The women held large white handkerchiefs to their eyes and wept silently. The children looked on with awe. No splinter, no visible remembrance was there. Wilhurst, Kentucky was gone. The water came in the night and took all things with it. Those few who now stared at the muddy yellow sand had come from the Branches to worship at the service for their dead. The cemetery lay quietly hidden on the hilltop. Here and there a greyed and weathered stone still marked a grave. Grass and weeds covered them all. They were of the hill. But seven fresh graves at the foot of the hill lay startling in their newness. No warmth covered them. Not yet. "Grandmother's there." "Two children are in this one." "Five bodies have not been found. " "My mother and father, here. " Their kin stood with them. They remembered their cries. Then . . . They walked on up the path to the hilltop and sat down. Not , one sob was heard. The grief was deep and restrained. A man sat with his arms around his wife and comforted her with soft whispers. A girl moved her fingers thru the cool grass. The mother who had been found in a tree sat alone. The water had torn her nine year old daughter from her arms. An uncle spoke to his sister. The preacher gave them hymn books. His wife set up the music rack. They all stood. The cornet sounded the first few notes. The song was sung straight out over the hills. And its refrain, "No tear-dimmed eyes - no sad farewells". They knelt in prayer. The preacher prayed. They bent over till their foreheads almost touched the ground. One hand covered their eyes. The other stretched out and held the earth. Each prayed his own prayer, aloud, and rocked with the mumbled chant. "Oh God! Praise the Lord! Yes, Lord. Oh God! Amen. Praise the Lord!" A peace fell upon them. And they were comforted.

rdf:Description.dc:title: George Washington Carver
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Petersen, Christian, 1885-1961.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Carver, George Washington, 1864?-1943; Petersen, Christian, 1885-1961.
rdf:Description.dc:description: Statue of George Washington Carver by Christian Petersen, sculptor-in-residence in the late 1940's. Originally a plaster sculpture, it was given to the University and placed in Carver Hall at the dedication of the hall in 1970 by the Class of 1968. Christian Petersen came over and stood by August Bang's side. "When I look upon Carver as you have him here, " Bang said, "The words which were written at his death come to my mind - 'He wandered with God'." "That is just what I have tried to say, " answered the artist, and a beautiful smile lighted his face. In 1998, with gift funds, the statue was cast in bronze as it was originally meant to be, and installed in the courtyard between Carver and Beardshear Halls.
